title: Sign font, sans serif, rounded edges,
author: Jgierula

comments.content: It looks like [Jackson MN](http://web.archive.org/web/20141007085217/http:/old.myfonts.com/fonts/itfmecanorma/jackson/) using am outlining method that blunted corners.

Good find Mike. All I can find out about this font is that it was by Bernard Jaquet, presumably a French or Swiss designer, and it was first used by the French dry-transfer lettering company, Mecanorma in 1971. [Source Identifont [http://www.identifont.com/show?1CG](http://web.archive.org/web/20141007085217/http:/www.identifont.com/show?1CG "http://www.identifont.com/show?1CG") and [http://www.identifont.com/show?273K](http://web.archive.org/web/20141007085217/http:/www.identifont.com/show?273K "http://www.identifont.com/show?273K") ]  
Do we know anything more?  
Don
Jackson was a [common choice](http://web.archive.org/web/20141007085217/http:/fontsinuse.com/typefaces/7819/jackson) for European small business signs in the 1970s–80s.

Thank you very much Stephen. Fonts in use is such a well researched site.  
Don

Thanks much for that, Stephen.

It's incredible that the same designer created Spring - digitized by Canada Type as [Jojo](http://web.archive.org/web/20141007085217/http:/old.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/jojo/). Maybe he had two personalities ...

It appears that Identifont and MyFonts (for Jackson) have Jacquet's name misspelled.

Another one that makes me dizzy -- the era of LSD, and something that would fit the Austin Powers movies as "groovy" -- I prefer the unique formalism of the other design.  
Don

[Luc Devroye](http://web.archive.org/web/20141007085217/http:/luc.devroye.org/fonts-44643.html) seems certain they are two different Jacquets, but [Hans Reichardt](http://web.archive.org/web/20141007085217/http:/www.klingspor-museum.de/KlingsporKuenstler/Schriftdesigner/Jacquet/BJacquet.pdf) (Klingspor) feels they are one and the same.
BTW, my Typophlile track link doesn't seem to include posts for the new(ish) Font ID forum. Is that true? Or am I missing a secret feature?

Stephen, this is a feature we lost when the new type ID board was created :(  
I followed the links in your earlier post and confirmed my impression that the digitization of Jackson MN is of poor quality compared to the original.  
Here are a few letters from the pre-digital era

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141007085217im_/http:/typophile.com/files/EgittoRipotecaItalianaExcerpt_4021.jpg)
  
The best quality image was from the Ripoteca Italiana version, so I used it for this excerpt. The Mecanorma dry transfer sheet looks the same.  
Here are a few letters from the digital Jackson MN  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141007085217im_/http:/typophile.com/files/JacksonMN_FO__6098.jpg)
  
Not only are the outlines sloppy, but height of the letters varies noticiably.  
Don

Jackson MN is based on a woodtype.  
See Nick Sherman's pic of a type drawer at the Tipoteca Italiana museum [https://www.flickr.com/photos/nicksherman/14169626150/in/pool-woodtype/](http://web.archive.org/web/20141007085217/https:/www.flickr.com/photos/nicksherman/14169626150/in/pool-woodtype/ "https://www.flickr.com/photos/nicksherman/14169626150/in/pool-woodtype/")  
Don
